awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research EaSM2: Mechanisms, Predictability, Prediction, and Regional and Societal Impacts of Decadal Climate Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit
Skillful decadal climate predictions have the potential to provide enormous social, economic, and environmental value. Such efforts, however, are in their infancy and many formidable scientific and technical challenges exist. Decadal prediction represents a combined initial value and boundary value problem in which prediction capabilities must be largely derived from the intrinsic variability of the climate system. In this project, through an interdisciplinary collaboration, the investigators seek i) to produce an improved and reliable decadal prediction system within the Community Earth System Model (CESM) framework, including predictive capabilities for marine ecosystems and biogeochemical constituents and ii) to advance the use of decadal prediction simulations in regional and societal impact studies. Attainment of these goals and developing a well-founded decadal prediction system will rely on improved understanding and technical capabilities in four fundamental areas. Thus, the research aims at (1) improving the understanding of intrinsic decadal variability and mechanisms; (2) evaluating the inherent predictability constraints of the current forecast model; (3) evaluating practical forecast system design methods; and (4) generating capabilities for incorporating fully-coupled data assimilation and ocean ecosystems and biogeochemistry into the NCAR decadal prediction system. The insights, knowledge, and capabilities developed from these objectives will then be used to establish a modeling and initialization strategy for making multi-decadal predictions. Regional and societal impact studies using the output from these decadal prediction experiments will be performed to advance the science of decadal prediction by pursuing and integrating research developments and insights across multiple relevant disciplines: climate dynamics, predictability, low- and high-resolution coupled climate modeling, data assimilation, biogeochemical and ecosystem modeling, regional weather forecasting, population dynamics, and fish habitats. The end result will be improved understanding of the limits and practical potential of decadal prediction, well-founded modeling and initialization strategies for making predictions, and advanced capabilities for downscaling and interpreting physical climate predictions for societal benefits.

Broader Impacts
This project will produce a well-founded decadal prediction system within the CESM framework that incorporates DART (Data Assimilation Research Testbed) and WRF (Weather Research and Forecast model). The prediction system, enhanced modeling capabilities, and results and data from our simulations will be made available to the broader research community via regular CESM and DART community releases as well as project web pages. These developments will serve as important community resources. This research project in its entirety is aimed at studying decadal climate variability in a socially relevant context. Specifically, the impacts of predicted decadal changes on winter storm events, summer heat waves, ocean ecosystems and biogeochemistry, human population, and fisheries' species ranges will be examined with a focus on North America and surrounding areas. Early career scientists, including a postdoc, will conduct much of the proposed work, and all the partnering institutions are are committed to mentoring activities to ensure success. In addition, two Ph. D. studies will include work from this proposal. Finally, at NCAR, the project team will host an annual student in the UCAR SOARS (Significant Opportunities in Atmospheric Research and Science; www.soars.ucar.edu) program to entrain a diverse community for the scientific workforce of the future.

Project Outcomes Report

Collaborative Research EaSM2: Mechanisms, Predictability, Prediction, and Regional and Societal Impacts of Decadal Climate Variability

A major end product of our interdisciplinary collaborative project is a well-founded and reliable decadal prediction (DP) system within the Community Earth System Model (CESM) framework that includes predictive capabilities for marine ecosystems and biogeochemical constituents. We have also advanced the use of our DP simulations in regional and societal impact studies. To achieve this DP system, we have substantially improved our understanding and technical capabilities in four fundamental areas: i) intrinsic decadal variability and mechanisms; ii) inherent predictability constraints of our forecast model; iii) practical forecast system design methods; and iv) generating capabilities for incorporating fully-coupled data assimilation and ocean ecosystems and biogeochemistry into our DP system.

We have produced a CESM Decadal Prediction Large Ensemble (DPLE) with 40 members. A paper documenting this major product was published in the September 2018 issue of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society. We have created a web page to provide information about our CESM-DPLE framework and to make the data sets freely available to the broader community (http://www.cesm.ucar.edu/projects/community-projects/DPLE/). Numerous groups from the US university community as well as the international climate science community have contacted our group to discuss collaborations and request help using the DPLE data. The DPLE is currently being uploaded to the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF) as the NCAR contribution to the Decadal Climate Prediction Project (DCPP) of the Coupled Model Inter-comparison Project phase 6 (CMIP6).

Our project directly contributed to numerous studies that analyze our DPLE simulations, also covering work on various regional and societal impacts and ecosystems. These include studies of: the predictability of global and regional ocean carbon uptake; the potential for skillful decadal prediction of winter precipitation over western Europe; the predictability of Atlantic tropical cyclones using a generation potential index computed from dynamically-predicted state fields; and the predictability of North Atlantic storm activity. We have also contributed to several ongoing DPLE-focused investigations, including topics such as: the mechanisms associated with summer precipitation predictability in the African Sahel, the predictability of ocean acidity in the California Current system, the potential for predicting ocean oxygen variability in the Pacific, ensemble information content and state-dependent predictability using the relative entropy metric, the potential for hybrid dynamical-statistical predictions of Atlantic cyclone frequency, the predictability of ocean heat waves, the predictability of dynamic sea level and coastal sea level extremes, and the mechanisms associated with the 2015 Atlantic cold blob and their representation in state-of-the-art DP systems. DPLE data has also been used in several new high-profile, multi-institution, many-author manuscripts featuring our project members as co-authors.

Our research on the predictability of extreme weather has identified the roles of sea surface temperature (SST) and sea-ice anomalies and natural variability on the landfall hurricanes in the US and the extreme winter weather in North America and Eurasia. We have found a specific SST anomaly pattern that has high predictive skill for the number of Atlantic hurricanes making landfall on the US east coast due to its impact on a favorable combination of atmospheric wind shear and sea level pressure. We have also found that the extreme weather events in North America in the winters of 2013 and 2015 can be largely explained by the SST anomalies surrounding the North American continent, while the extreme events in the 2014 winter are primarily caused by atmospheric natural variability. Our results show that the predictability of societally relevant extreme weather on seasonal and longer time scales vary from year to year and from region to region, depending on the magnitude and patterns of SST and sea ice anomalies that have longer predictive time scales. 

In addition to advancing our nation?s DP capabilities, making our data sets freely available to the broader community, and many societally-relevant studies listed above, broader impacts of our project include training and development of five graduate students and three under-graduate students, including a SOARS (Significant Opportunities in Atmospheric Research and Science) protege. Results on US landfall hurricanes from the project have been introduced to New York state agencies to aid their design of resilience strategies for better preparation against future coastal storms.
